header_summary:
Andrew Toth's introduction of a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) for generating and verifying discrete logarithm equality proofs over the secp256k1 elliptic curve aims to bolster the security of silent payments in Bitcoin. This proposal, motivated by enhancing the reliability of Partially Signed Bitcoin Transactions (PSBTs), leverages zero-knowledge proofs to ensure the correctness of output scripts without compromising private keys, addressing a crucial requirement by BIP352. The effort underscores a significant advancement in cryptographic practices within the Bitcoin ecosystem, promoting safer encrypted transactions ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/b0f40eab-42f3-4153-8083-b455fbd17e19n@googlegroups.com/T/#u#md54f948a215a1d828571be3122954b53fdf40b96)).

Antoine Riard discusses the development and testing of the libbitcoinkernel projects and the bitcoind build system, aiming to run the bitcoin consensus engine in a secure enclave to minimize security threats. The project, detailed in a newly public repository, marks a step forward in bitcoin development, offering a foundation for new full-node implementations and enhancing security and diversity in bitcoin node implementations. This initiative emphasizes the importance of clear documentation and community feedback for its ongoing development and potential integration with other programming languages ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/62313198-398b-42a5-92bd-dfcc57434d55n@googlegroups.com/T/#u#m47cf1cb1c648b8812367a2a18b6e6828653d9def)).

The discussions by conduition and GaloisField2718 highlight the bitcoin community's proactive stance on quantum resistance and the exploration of Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs) within blockchain technology. Conduition's strategy for a transitional framework to post-quantum secure keys without immediate consensus changes and the exploration of Winternitz OTS for emergency fallback demonstrates a careful approach to future-proofing Bitcoin against quantum threats. Meanwhile, GaloisField2718's inquiry into the practicality of ZKPs and their integration with covenants reflects a growing interest in advancing blockchain verification processes and the application of theoretical cryptographic concepts to real-world scenarios ([Conduition's source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/proposing-a-p2qrh-bip-towards-a-quantum-resistant-soft-fork/956/3), [GaloisField2718's source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/bitcoin-pipes-covenants-on-bitcoin-without-soft-fork/1195/2)).

recent_posts.title: BIP: DLEQ
recent_posts.summary:
- The BIP introduces a method for generating/verifying DLEQ proofs over secp256k1 for Bitcoin security.
- It aims at enhancing silent payment security in PSBTs and supports ECDH operations without key disclosure.
- The proposal details algorithms for DLEQ proof generation/verification to ensure correct cryptographic operations.

recent_posts.title: On Libbitcoinkernel Readyness
recent_posts.summary:
- Efforts were made to enhance bitcoind and develop libbitcoinkernel for secure bitcoin consensus.
- A standalone libbitcoinkernel repository is now public for clearer documentation and wider accessibility.
- The project encourages integrating the consensus engine with Rust and seeks feedback to improve.

recent_posts.title: Proposing a P2QRH BIP towards a quantum resistant soft fork
recent_posts.summary:
- Quantum resistance in cryptography is key for Bitcoin's future against quantum computing threats.
- A transition strategy involves hash-based signatures to prepare for eventual quantum challenges.
- The approach includes emergency fallback mechanisms and defers consensus changes, focusing on long-term security.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin PIPEs: Covenants on Bitcoin Without Soft Fork
recent_posts.summary:
- The email discusses implementing Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs) within PIPE setups and verification.
- It addresses technicalities of data encryption and the push of ciphertext in blockchain contexts.
- Questions are raised about the practical application and feasibility of theoretical concepts.

active_posts.title: Signing a Bitcoin Transaction with Lamport Signatures (no changes needed)
active_posts.summary:
- An innovative Bitcoin transaction method was developed at MIT DCI using Lamport signatures.
- This method relies on ECDSA signatures' variable lengths, avoiding OP_CAT, and introduces unique security challenges.
- Proposed improvements focus on mitigating weaknesses and enhancing security through diverse signature lengths.

active_posts.title: Redefine packages to discourage address reuse
active_posts.summary:
- Address reuse in Bitcoin transactions threatens privacy, prompting proposal for mempool policy change.
- BIP 331's definition of package transactions may enhance privacy by preventing address reuse.
- Challenges include increased scanning times and potential resistance to amending Bitcoin Core standards.

active_posts.title: Proposal for Quantum-Resistant Cryptography in Bitcoin - BIP Submission
active_posts.summary:
- The BIP aims to introduce quantum-resistant cryptography to Bitcoin, featuring SPHINCS+ and Dilithium.
- Proposed modifications include a new address format and updates to transaction structures for quantum resistance.
- Agustín Cruz seeks community feedback on the proposal, available for review at a GitHub URL.

active_posts.title: Bolt 12 Trusted Contacts
active_posts.summary:
- Bolt 12 enhances lightning wallets by introducing metadata offers and contact management.
- It proposes a system for selective identity sharing in transactions, emphasizing user privacy.
- Feedback is sought to refine identity revelation methods in Bolt 12, focusing on user experience.

active_posts.title: Non-disclosure of a consensus bug in btcd
active_posts.summary:
- In March 2024, a consensus bug in btcd was found and fixed in version 0.24.2.
- Transparency in disclosing security flaws, despite delayed requests, is emphasized by the authors.
- Around 16 btcd nodes remain at risk after a security update, urging an immediate upgrade.

active_posts.title: LN Summit 2024 Notes & Summary/Commentary
active_posts.summary:
- Over thirty Lightning developers met in Tokyo to discuss Lightning and Bitcoin protocols.
- Innovations like anchor outputs and PTLCs were proposed to improve transaction reliability and privacy.
- The summit encouraged future innovations for enhancing the Lightning Network's scalability and usability.

today_in_history_posts.title: BIP- & SLIP-0039 -- better multi-language support
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Weiji Guo highlights BIP-0039's reliance on language for mnemonic sentence generation.
- Guo proposes using third-party tools for mnemonic translations and numerical seed representation.
- He seeks community input on the implementation of his suggestions for better inclusivity.

today_in_history_posts.title: RFC: simplifications and suggestions on open/accept limits.
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Gert-Jaap Glasbergen opposes removing htlc_minimum_msat to prevent trimmed HTLCs.
- He suggests adjusting "dust" definition with fees and chain-specific minimum_depth.
- Rusty disagrees on parts below 1000 msat, citing sub-satoshi fees making one inoperable.

today_in_history_posts.title: Segwit Ephemeral Anchors
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Ephemeral Anchors allow key-less output types but are prone to transaction ID malleability.
- Initial "OP_TRUE" solution is deemed inefficient due to high cost and redundancy.
- Proposed alternative uses bip141 to reduce extra bytes and simplify implementation on a special branch.
